div.l: And many a Iak of Douer hast thou solde
That hath ben twies hoot and twies colde
Of many a pilgrim hast thou cristes curs
For of thi persele yit fare they the wers
That they han eten in thi stoble goos
For in thi shoppe is many a flie loos
Now tel on gentil Roger be thi name
But yit I pray the be nat wroth for game
A man may sey full soth in game and pleie
Thou seist ful soth quod Roger be my fey
But such pley quade pley as the fleming seith
And therfor Herri bailly be thi feith
Be thou nat wroth or we departe hiere
Thouȝ that my tale be of an hostillere
But natheles I will nat telle it yit
But or we departe I wis thou shalt be quit
And therwith all he lough and made chere
And seid his tale as ye shal aftir hiere

l.hi: iere beginneth the tale of the Cook of London̄

div.l:
A prentys whilom duellid
in oure cite ·
Of a craft of vitaillers was he
And gailard was he as a goldfinch in the shawe
Broun as a beri a propre short felawe
With lokkes blake kembed ful fetisly
Daunce he coude so wel and iolily
That he was cleped Perkyn Reuelour
He was as full of Loue and paramour
As is the hive full of hony swete
Wel was the wenche that him miȝt mete
At eueri bridale wold he singe ⁊and hoppe
He loued better the tauerne than the shoppe
For whan there any riding was in chepe
Out of the shoppe thider wold he lepe
Til that he had al the siȝt I sein
And daunced wel he wold nat come agein̄
And gadered him a meny of his sort
To harpe and singe ⁊and make such disport
